title: Retell Timeline Foundations
description: Timeline contrast practice: background action vs interrupting event.

items.sentence: She was studying when the lights went out.
items.hint: Past continuous usually marks the longer background action.
items.explanation: Past continuous sets the background; past simple marks the interrupting event.

items.sentence: They were walking home when it started to rain.
items.hint: Look for was/were + verb-ing for background timeline.
items.explanation: The walking was in progress. The rain starting is the shorter interrupting event.

items.sentence: I was writing notes when the teacher called my name.

fragments.text: when the teacher called my name

items.explanation: Writing notes is the background action. The call happened at one point in that timeline.

items.sentence: The class was discussing the article when the bell rang.

fragments.text: The class was discussing the article

items.hint: The ring is a short event. The discussion is background.
items.explanation: The discussion continued over time; the bell ring interrupted that flow.

items.sentence: Mina was opening her laptop when the internet failed.
items.explanation: Opening the laptop is the background process; internet failure is the completed interruption.

items.sentence: We were reviewing examples when the projector turned off.
items.hint: Reviewing lasted longer than the one-time turn-off event.
items.explanation: Reviewing formed the background timeline, and projector shutdown interrupted it.

items.sentence: Students were revising, the projector was flickering, and then the power failed.
items.hint: Director mode can include more than one background action.
items.explanation: Two simultaneous background actions can exist. The failed power event is the interruption.

items.sentence: I was organizing folders, the app was syncing, and suddenly the screen froze.
items.hint: Use tense role, not sentence position, to decide placement.
items.explanation: Organizing and syncing are ongoing. Screen freeze is completed and interruptive.

items.sentence: While they were practicing, the coach entered.
items.explanation: The while-clause gives background duration; entering is the short completed event.

items.sentence: The bus was moving when a cyclist crossed in front of it.

fragments.text: when a cyclist crossed in front of it

items.hint: Crossed is completed; moving is ongoing.
items.explanation: The crossing happened at one point during the longer movement event.

items.sentence: The team was checking clues, students were taking notes, and the alarm sounded.
items.hint: Director mode may include two background tracks.
items.explanation: Checking clues and taking notes are ongoing. Alarm sounded is the interrupting completed event.

items.sentence: She was presenting the slide when the file disappeared.
items.hint: Presentation = ongoing process; disappearance = point event.
items.explanation: Presenting was continuous in time. The disappearance interrupted that process.
